text.headline:
民國62-67年
政大校園地圖
text.text: 1973-1978 NCCU Campus Map

media.caption:
社資中心全名為「社會科學資料中心」，其前身為天放樓（於民國79年拆除，改建為資訊大樓），為加強學校資料文獻的保存，乃在山下校區東北角（希賢新村）新徵購之土地上興建新一代的社資中心，並獲得國家科學委員會500萬元的補助。為使該工程合乎使用需要，特公開登報徵求設計圖樣，並聘請學者專家評審，由入選第一名的華泰建築師事務所承辦設計與監造。

民國61年4月17日開工，歷時一年半載，於62年10月2日完工，同月30日上午十時劉前校長季洪主持落成啟鑰儀式，並邀請新舊任校長暨各單位主管參加。新建大樓佔地335坪，總工程費約1,000萬元。內部除設閱覽室、期刊室、會議室、辦公室、視聽教室外，並設置教授研究室與研究生研究室，可容納700個座位。全樓裝設中央系統冷氣及升降電梯。規模宏偉，設備之完善，在國內均首屈一指。設備最完整的社資中四層大樓之落成，對本校研究與教學有莫大的裨益。

新建的社資中心，由於藏書資料迅速增加而不敷使用，民國65年李元簇校長以「因圖書資料增加已不容納亟待擴建應需要」簽請教育部核准擴建。擴建部分為地上四層地下一層之大樓，總面積為7,048平方公尺，地上各層四周均設隔間獨用的研究室，供教授及研究生撰寫論文，70年3月11日開標，由天工營造公司得標承包，5月4日開工，71年12月擴建工程完工；72年10間內部設備全部完工。77年間，前棟外牆因地震受損而加整修並將原先瓷磚牆面改為洗石子。

經歷五十年來的變遷，民國110年社資中心因應校園整體空間規劃遷出該棟大樓內辦公單位，此建築物完成階段性任務，走入歷史。

media.credit: Caroline Miller House; Photo from Vanishing South Georgia by Brian Brown

text.headline: Baxley
text.text: Born in Waycross, Georgia, Caroline Miller moved to Baxley shortly after graduating high school and marrying her former English teacher. Overwhelmed by the workaday struggles of raising three young boys, she took her sons on long drives through the surrounding countryside, collecting in her notebook the folktales and speech patterns that became the basis for her first novel, Lamb in His Bosom. Though Miller had no formal training, she was praised for her faithful depiction of wiregrass dialect and culture, and her best-selling novel won the Pulitzer Prize in 1934—making Miller the first Georgian to win the award for fiction.

media.credit: Andalusia Farm; Photo from Georgia College and State University

text.headline: Milledgeville
text.text: Andalusia Farm in Milledgeville is widely known both as the place where Flannery O'Connor penned her most important works—Wise Blood and A Good Man is Hard to Find among them—and as the home of her prized collection of peafowl. On the farm, often with only her mother and beloved “peachickens” for company, O'Connor perfected the dark humor and peculiar characters that came to define her work. Commenting on the prevalence of the grotesque in her fiction, O'Connor noted: “Whenever I’m asked why Southern writers particularly have a penchant for writing about freaks, I say it is because we are still able to recognize one."

media.credit: Alice Walker Childhood Home; Photo from Explore Georgia

text.headline: Eatonton
text.text: Just a few miles from Milledgeville, Alice Walker was born the daughter of sharecroppers and the youngest of eight siblings. A precocious child, Walker nurtured a passion for reading and writing from an early age. She left Eatonton at eighteen, studying first at Spelman College in Atlanta and then at Sarah Lawrence in New York. Though she eventually settled in California, Walker's creative roots remained in the rural South. Her best-known novel, the Pulitzer Prize–winning The Color Purple (1983), portrays economic hardship and generational violence in a small Georgia town not unlike Eatonton. An accomplished poet, activist, and sometimes controversial figure, Walker is also credited with restoring the literary legacy of another southern writer—Zora Neale Hurston.

media.credit: Lillian E. Smith Center; Photo from Piedmont College

text.headline: Clayton
text.text: When Lillian Smith's Strange Fruit was published in 1944, the book sparked controversy nationwide and condemnation in her home state. The novel, which features an interracial relationship, was banned by both the state of Massachusetts and the U.S. Post Office, and denounced by Georgia governor Eugene Talmadge as a "literary corncob." Snubbed by her neighbors, Smith continued to speak out against segregation and social inequity. From her home atop Old Screamer Mountain in Clayton, Smith—along with her partner Paula Snelling—ran a girls camp, published a literary magazine, and corresponded with Martin Luther King Jr. Today, her home is the Lillian E. Smith Center, an educational center and artists retreat on the campus of Piedmont College.

media.credit: Reece Heritage Farm

text.headline: Blairsville
text.text: Raised near the foothills of Blood Mountain, Byron Herbert Reece's early life was so isolated that it's rumored he didn't see a car until he was eight or twelve years old. A bright but solitary child, "Hub" Reece published his first poem in the local paper while he was still in high school and studied briefly at Young Harris College before returning to work on his family's farm. There, he toiled by day and wrote by night, producing Ballad of the Bones, a collection of poetry shaped by the cadences of scripture and the rhythms of farm life. Though its publication brought literary acclaim, and Reece went on to write three more volumes of poetry and two novels, his traditional, rhyming ballads fell out of favor in a decade dominated by the Beats.

media.credit: Margaret Mitchell House; Photo from Atlanta History Center

text.headline: Atlanta
text.text: During her four years on the staff of the Atlanta Journal Sunday Magazine, Margaret Mitchell wrote book reviews, profiles, and the occasional advice column until complications from an ankle injury ended her career as a journalist. Using an old sewing table as a desk, she then set to work on the manuscript that would become Gone With the Wind, the single best-selling novel of the twentieth century. Easy to read, but sometimes hard to stomach, the book made an indelible mark on popular culture, for better or worse. Its film adaptation was no less successful, earning rave reviews and eight academy awards—a record that stood for two decades. The film’s lavish premiere at the Loew’s Grand Theater was an event unlike any in the city’s history, and the reason the Olympics are only the second-biggest thing ever to happen in Atlanta.

media.credit: The Wren's Nest

text.headline: Atlanta
text.text: A working journalist for most of his professional life, Joel Chandler Harris spent twenty-four years as a columnist and editor at the Atlanta Constitution. But it was his Uncle Remus tales that ensured his literary fame. Based on stories told by former slaves, the tales found a wide audience in the late nineteenth and early twentieth centuries when folklore was a publishing phenomenon. Some contemporary critics have been less sympathetic, observing that Harris profited handsomely from African American storytelling, while others credit him for preserving oral traditions that might have otherwise been lost. The Wren’s Nest, where Harris made his home, is among the finest examples of early Victorian Queen Anne residential architecture in the city and now houses an educational center that features innovative programming and serves diverse audiences.

media.credit: The Little Manse; Photo from Vanishing North Georgia, Brian Brown

text.headline: Moreland
text.text: Erskine Caldwell had an itinerant youth thanks to his circuit-riding father, a minister in the Associate Reformed Presbyterian Church. But the poverty he witnessed as a young man in Georgia left its stamp on both Caldwell and his fiction, particularly his best-selling masterwork,  Tobacco Road. For his part, Caldwell was unequivocal when describing his relationship to the state, telling infamous Governor Lester Maddox, “I like to think I’m as much a Georgian as Brer Rabbit.”

media.credit: Carson McCullers Center for Writers and Musicians

text.headline: Columbus
text.text: Carson McCullers seldom had kind words for folks back home in her native Columbus and, for many years, the feeling was mutual. Columbus society was scandalized by the free-spirited McCullers whose work explored complex themes of sexuality, voyeurism, and obsession. But whatever enmity may have existed between the town and its prodigal daughter has long since passed. In 2017, Columbus hosted a series of readings and events to celebrate the centenary of McCullers’ birth, and Columbus State University now operates the remarkable Carson McCullers Center for Writers and Musicians to preserve her legacy and foster the talents of young creatives.

media.credit: Tuskegee University Library ; Photo from Jcooper3105n

text.headline: Tuskegee
text.text: Albert Murray and Ralph Ellison first met at the library on the campus of the Tuskegee Normal and Industrial Institute (later Tuskegee University). The year was 1935. Murray was a freshman; Ellison was a junior, with a job at the circulation desk. After WWII, they reconnected in New York City because of their Tuskegee background. Murray was attending graduate school in the city, and Ellison, who lived there, began sharing passages of a novel he was working on, Invisible Man. Their mutual passion for ideas, words, and music fueled a lifelong friendship and inspired writings that challenged readers' understanding of identity. The campus that nurtured these passions, and where Murray also taught literature and composition before the war, retains many elements of their time there, including the famed statue, “Lifting the Veil of Ignorance.”

media.credit: The Scott & Zelda Fitzgerald Museum; Photo from Chris Pruitt

text.headline: Montgomery
text.text: The city of Montgomery was Zelda Sayre’s playground. The storied belle entertained herself on the marble stairs of the state capitol with her friends Sara Haardt and Tallulah Bankhead. She skated down its hilly streets, became a champion swimmer and diver in its pools, and daydreamed at its historic sites. On a summer evening in 1918, F. Scott Fitzgerald, an aspiring author stationed at a military training camp in town, first caught sight of her performing a solo ballet dance at a country club party. Zelda and Scott married and became icons of the Jazz Age. They gained notoriety in New York City and Europe, but Alabama remained a part of their literary works. The last home the two would share as husband and wife was in Montgomery. It was there that they wrote portions of their respective novels, Save Me The Waltz and Tender Is The Night. The residence is now a museum dedicated to their legacy.

media.credit: Downtown Hartselle; Photo from Chris Pruitt

text.headline: Hartselle
text.text: William “Bill” Bradford Huie, a sixth-generation Alabamian, was born in Hartselle and died, seventy-six years later, less than fifty miles down the road in Guntersville. Parts of Huie’s life were typical of a white, high school valedictorian of his generation: graduating from the University of Alabama, working in Birmingham, and serving in the military during WWII. His highly autobiographical first novel, Mud on the Stars, depicts those years. Less typical were his honest writings about ordinary people, race relations, violence, sex, war, and injustice. Huie wrote twenty-three books, seven of which were adapted as movies. His practice of “checkbook journalism” earned him scorn from his professional colleagues. His coverage of the civil rights movement had people burning crosses in his yard. Huie’s books sold more than 30 million copies, and yet at the time of his death, none of them were still in print. The public library in Hartselle’s historic downtown area, which was renamed in Huie’s honor, has an exhibit on the writer’s life and works.

media.credit: Bluff Hall; Photo from Marengo County Historical Society

text.headline: Demopolis
text.text: Lillian Hellman’s childhood visits with her maternal grandparents in Demopolis, a town on the chalk bluffs of the Tombigbee River, influenced one of her more enduring plays. However, her portrayal of family relations driven by avarice did not endear Hellman to her Alabama kin. The Hubbard characters in her plays The Little Foxes and Another Part of the Forest were shaped by her impression of affluent relatives who helped build the town, including establishing a bank, which still stands. And the local architectural gems Bluff Hall and Lyon Hall are presumed to have inspired the descriptions of Birdie Hubbard’s beloved plantation home, Lionnet. Hellman also wrote the screenplay for the film adaptation of The Little Foxes, which was directed by William Wyler. Wyler’s wife, actress Margaret Tallichet, was also from a family with roots in Demopolis.

media.credit: Old Courthouse Museum; Photo from Monroe County Museum

text.headline: Monroeville
text.text: Maycomb, the fictional setting for Harper Lee’s beloved novel To Kill A Mockingbird, was shaped by her hometown, Monroeville—a sleepy southern community without paved roads that was populated with residents who knew one another’s business. Her family lived a few blocks from the county courthouse, where she watched her lawyer father try cases. Its courtroom was reproduced as a set for the movie based on Lee’s novel, and a theatrical production based on To Kill A Mockingbird is performed each spring at the courthouse square. The cemetery where Lee is buried is less than a mile from the courthouse museum that preserves the space that has inspired millions of readers. (Monroeville is also the hometown of Pulitzer Prize–winning journalist Cynthia Tucker and the birthplace of bestselling novelist Mark Childress.)

media.credit: Monroe County Museum; Photo from Wmr36104

text.headline: Monroeville
text.text: During his childhood, Truman Capote was often left in the care of older relatives in Monroeville. As a result, he was Harper Lee’s next-door neighbor during the 1930s. The two budding writers shared secrets in a chinaberry tree refuge and relied upon their youthful imaginations for entertainment in depression-era Monroeville. The tomboy character of Idabel in Other Voices, Other Rooms, Capote's first novel, is modeled after Lee; Dill in Lee’s To Kill A Mockingbird was modeled after him. Two of his autobiographical short stories, “A Christmas Memory” and “The Thanksgiving Visitor,” drew upon his life in the town. The place where November skies announced “it’s fruitcake weather,” honors the author with a permanent exhibit in the county courthouse. There is also a historical marker at the lot where the home of his Faulk cousins once stood.

media.credit: Bienville Square; Photo from Altairisfar

text.headline: Mobile
text.text: “When all else fails, throw a party!” Thus prescribed Eugene Walter, Mobile’s famed raconteur, who entertained friends and strangers with southern wit and excellent food. The Mobile of his youth was a multicultural port city that featured hectic banana docks, fresh bay oysters, wide front porches, Mardi Gras festivities, and live oaks on Bienville Square. In The Untidy Pilgrim, he called it “sweet lunacy’s county seat.” Mobile's “south of the salt line” attitude imbues his works. On the evening before his funeral, Walter’s friends gathered at the Cathedral-Basilica of the Immaculate Conception to paint his coffin. They buried him at Church Street Graveyard, next to the man who revived Mobile’s Mardi Gras celebrations.

media.credit: Waterman Globe; Photo from University of South Alabama

text.headline: Mobile
text.text: Mobile native William March’s first novel, Company K, may not be set in Alabama, but the WWI story first took form in the letters he wrote to family members in Mobile. And Alabama is the setting, in the form of the fictionalized Pearl County and Reedyville, of four of his novels and many of his short stories. His last book, The Bad Seed, which was finished a month before he died in New Orleans, has a distinct Mobile influence. The novel’s main characters, the Penmarks, lived in a place that is recognizable as the Antoinette Apartments on Government Street. March’s career as a businessman was spent with the Waterman Shipping Corporation, which was established in Mobile in 1919, the year March returned home from the war. The company’s headquarters on St. Joseph Street featured a twelve-foot, rotating globe and multistory murals in its lobby. The murals remain in their original location; the globe now resides in the Mitchell Center at the University of South Alabama.

media.credit: Africatown Cemetery; Photo from Leigh T Harrell

text.headline: Mobile
text.text: Albert Murray’s first published novel, Train Whistle Guitar, transported readers to the world of his childhood, Mobile’s Magazine Point community in the 1920s. It was in Mobile that “tell-me-tale times” connected him to Africatown and the slave ship Clotilde, and folklore about the likes of Railroad Bill. Murray’s Mobile, his briar patch, had history and tradition, docks and trains, and jazz and blues that connected the place to the world at large. An essayist and man of letters, the author of The Omni-Americans composed three more novels featuring the protagonist Scooter, a schoolboy from Gasoline Point, who had a tall chinaberry tree in his front yard that gave him a view of the world and rooted him in Alabama.

media.credit: Tennessee Williams Home and Welcome Center; Photo from Southern Literary Trail

text.headline: Columbus
text.text: Thomas “Tennessee” Lanier Williams III—one of the greatest playwrights in American history—was born in Columbus. He was the second-born child of Edwina Dakin, the daughter of Rev. Walter Dakin, and Cornelius Williams, a traveling salesman and a heavy drinker and gambler. When Cornelius was away from home, which was frequently, Edwina and her children would stay with her parents in Columbus, and later Clarksdale, until 1918 when Cornelius took a job in St. Louis and demanded his family come with him. The birthplace of Tennessee Williams, now the Columbus Welcome Center, is open to the public, and the town hosts the Tennessee Williams Tribute festival each year.

media.credit: Mississippi University for Women; Photo from MUW Alumni Association

text.headline: Columbus
text.text: After graduating from Jackson High School, Eudora Welty enrolled at the Mississippi State College for Women (now Mississippi University for Women), the first state-supported college for women in the United States. While at MUW, Welty discovered her love of poetry and wrote and drew for the Spectator, the campus newspaper. She spent two years there before moving on to the University of Wisconsin at Madison, where she earned a bachelor’s degree in English. Today, the annual Eudora Welty Writers’ Symposium at MUW attracts authors and scholars of global prominence.

media.credit: William Faulkner Literary Garden; Photo from Union County Heritage Museum

text.headline: New Albany
text.text: Nobel Prize–winner William Faulkner, one of the most celebrated literary figures in American history, was born in 1897 in New Albany, Mississippi, the seat of Union County. At the age of five, his family moved to Oxford, where Faulkner would live for most of his life. The counties surrounding Lafayette County in North Mississippi, such as Union County, provided inspiration for Faulkner’s famous Yoknapatawpha County. Today, the Union County Heritage Museum, located just one block from the site of Faulkner’s birth, celebrates the life of the renowned writer and the local connections found in his works, including his last novel The Reivers (1962), which won the Pulitzer Prize for fiction.

media.credit: Union County Heritage Museum; Photo from Mississippi Museums Association

text.headline: New Albany
text.text: Writer Borden Deal spent his childhood in the farming communities around Pontotoc and New Albany, Mississippi, until his family lost its land during the Great Depression. The family relocated to a communal farming project in Enterprise, where Deal stayed until the death of his father in 1936. The best known of Deal’s twenty-one novels are set in the American South, including Dunbar’s Cove (1957), a novel about the Tennessee Valley Authority, and The Insolent Breed (1959), a story about hillbilly music and humanity’s fight against encroaching civilization. His works and legacy are celebrated at the Union County Heritage Museum in New Albany.

media.credit: Rowan Oak; Photo from University of Mississippi Museum

text.headline: Oxford
text.text: Most of William Faulkner’s works are set in the town of Jefferson, seat of the fictional Yoknapatawpha County, a place largely inspired by his hometown of Oxford, the political seat of Lafayette County. In 1929, Faulkner published both Sartoris, his first novel set in Yoknapatawpha County, and The Sound and the Fury. That same year, he married his former high school sweetheart, Estelle Oldham Franklin, and they settled in Oxford. The following year, Faulkner published As I Lay Dying and purchased Rowan Oak, the Greek Revival house he would call home for the rest of his life. His daughter, Jill Faulkner Summers, eventually sold the house to the University of Mississippi, and today guests can tour the home, which contains much of the Faulkner family’s original furnishings.

media.credit: Downtown Como; Photo from Jimmy Emerson, DVM

text.headline: Como
text.text: Stark Young—famed novelist, poet, playwright, essayist, dramatist, professor, painter, and theater critic—lived in Como and Panola County until he was eight years old. He spent much of his childhood in the care of his maternal aunts and his uncle, who imparted the traditional southern perspective that would shape much of his work. During the early 1920s and early 1930s, Young wrote four novels set in Mississippi, each inspired by locales in Como: Heaven Trees (1926), The Torches Flare (1928), River House (1929), and his most famous work, So Red the Rose (1934), a Civil War saga that juxtaposes northern industrial society against southern agrarian life, a frequent theme in both his fiction and nonfiction. Young died in New York on January 6, 1963, and is buried in the Friendship Cemetery in Como.

media.credit: Tennessee Williams Park; Photo from John Padgett

text.headline: Clarksdale
text.text: In 1917, when Tennessee Williams was three years old, his family moved from Columbus to Clarksdale, where his grandfather served as the rector of Clarksdale’s St. George’s Episcopal Church. The playwright visited his grandfather often as a child and later remembered feeling awed by social functions hosted by Blanche Clark (the daughter of Clarksdale founder, John Clark) and her husband, J. W. Cutrer. The Cutrers and their mansion inspired character names and settings in several works by Williams, including The Glass Menagerie (1944) and A Streetcar Named Desire (1947). Today, Clarksdale is home to the Tennessee Williams Park and the annual Mississippi Delta Tennessee Williams Festival, during which porch plays are performed in Clarksdale’s historic district.

media.credit: River Boat at Greenville; Photo from Jimmy Smith

text.headline: Greenville
text.text: Shelby Foote was born in Greenville, Mississippi, the descendant of wealthy Delta planters. In 1930, he made a lifelong friendship with fellow writers, William Alexander Percy and Walker Percy, after the elder Percy requested that Foote show his teenage cousins around Greenville. Though he wrote fiction—four of his five novels centered on the Delta and are set in fictional  Jordan County and its county seat, Bristol, which closely resemble Washington County and Greenville—he is best known as a historian of the Civil War. Foote dedicated twenty years to writing a trilogy about the conflict and became famous through his commentary in Ken Burns’s 1990 documentary series The Civil War.

media.credit: Washington County Courthouse; Photo from Jimmy Emerson, DVM

text.headline: Greenville
text.text: National Book Award–winning novelist Walker Percy was born in Birmingham, Alabama, in 1916. Following the tragic deaths of his parents, Percy and his two brothers moved to Greenville, Mississippi, in 1930 to live with their second cousin, William Alexander Percy. In Greenville, Percy was introduced to the world of literature by his “Uncle Will,” who, as a lawyer and aristocratic planter, was a prominent member of the Delta’s ruling class, and as a poet and a writer was at the center of Greenville's artistic and cultural community. His elder cousin also introduced Percy to lifelong friend and fellow Greenville writer, Shelby Foote.

media.credit: Richard Wright Library ; Photo from Jackson-Hinds Library System

text.headline: Jackson
text.text: Of the myriad places Richard Wright lived in his youth, the one that offered him the most consistency was Jackson, where his maternal grandmother lived, and where he remained to earn an education from 1920 to 1925. Wright wrote about his strict grandmother, a devout Seventh-day Adventist who “informed his understanding of the folk mind and southern black culture,” in his autobiography, Black Boy (1945). Always challenging authority and religious doctrine, Wright published his first story, “The Voodoo of Hell’s Half-Acre” in the Southern Register, a black Jackson newspaper, at the age of fifteen. Though a good student, Wright dropped out of high school in 1925 at the age of seventeen and moved to Memphis (and later Chicago and New York) to work and write, eventually securing literary fame with the publication of his landmark novel Native Son (1940).

media.credit: Ayer Hall, JSU, home of the Margeret Walker Center; Photo from Charlie Ali

text.headline: Jackson
text.text: Born in Birmingham to gifted parents, Margaret Walker was groomed from birth for literary acclaim. She befriended Richard Wright while working for the WPA Chicago Writers’ Project and later belonged to a literary milieu that included some of the most celebrated black authors of the twentieth century. Her most notable works include her first collection of poetry, For My People (1942), which won the Yale Series of Younger Poets Competition, and her only novel, Jubilee (1966), which earned her the Houghton Mifflin Literary Fellowship Award. In 1949, she moved to Mississippi and joined the faculty of Jackson State College (later Jackson State University), where she taught English for thirty years. While a member of the faculty, she played an integral part in developing and nurturing the university’s humanities and honors programs, though her greatest and longest-lasting effort was the Institute for the Study of the History, Life, and Culture of Black People, which was later renamed the Margaret Walker Center. Founded by Walker in 1968, the center houses an array of collections that document the African American experience.

media.credit: Eudora Welty House and Garden; Photo from Eudora Welty Foundation

text.headline: Jackson
text.text: Eudora Welty was born in a house located on North Congress Street in Jackson in 1909. Only the Capitol Building separated her childhood home from the Carnegie Library, where her mother encouraged her to read any book she wanted, as frequently as possible. When she was sixteen, her family moved to the house at 1119 Pinehurst Street, across from Belhaven College for Young Ladies (later Belhaven University), where she lived until her death in 2001, at the age of ninety-two. It was in this house that Welty wrote almost all of her fiction and short stories. Welty bequeathed her house to the state of Mississippi, and visitors of the literary museum can see how she left her home, with the exterior, interior, furnishings, and gardens all meticulously preserved. Today, the Eudora Welty House is designated a National Historic Landmark and listed on the National Register of Historic Places.

media.credit: Mississippi Bridge in Natchez; Photo from Axel Magard

text.headline: Natchez
text.text: Richard Wright was born in 1908, on Rucker Plantation, in rural Adams County, approximately twenty miles outside Natchez. From the time of his birth, Wright experienced frequent displacement and intense poverty, experiences he explores in his autobiography Black Boy (1945). Wright’s father moved the family to Memphis when Wright was seven, only to desert the family soon after. Wright spent the remainder of his adolescence moving from place to place and staying with different relatives as a result of his mother’s poor health. Wright’s early childhood home, where he lived with his grandparents, is located in Natchez and bears a historical marker. The highway that leads into Natchez, an origination point for the Natchez Trace Parkway, is also named in Wright’s honor.

text.headline: Thanks, y'all!
text.text:
This story map is the result of a collaboration between the Encyclopedia of Alabama, Mississippi Encyclopedia, New Georgia Encyclopedia, and the Southern Literary Trail ®. The Trail is headquartered with an office and permanent display gallery in the Mitchell Library at Mississippi State University.

Thank you for exploring the trail with us. Read on and read South!
